Articles.Content:
To start, what I am asking after are other world colonies, I am NOT talking about orbital construction yards which I absolutely understand and agree with as a progression goal; that's cool stuff. Also, this is from the perspective of the progression gameplay, not sandbox. E: Should also add, I am not at all opposed to the stated interstellar goal (one of the dev videos) of setting up a "new KSC" at the target system. That's fine, it's basically duplicating what I'm already used to.

What purpose will colonies serve within the progression-based game? I ask this because I dislike management-style gameplay and usually avoid such games. I am especially disdainful of tacking on base-building elements to existing gameplay for what I consider no real reason.

  • If colonies are a required management and gameplay goal to provide necessary resources for future exploration then that, IMO, flies in the face of the stated gameplay goals of KSP, those being building and flying cool spaceships. That would require time spent designing, optimizing, crewing, and managing these colonies as opposed to exploring the solar system(s). That is not why I am looking forward to playing KSP2 and I think the progression gameplay would suffer greatly from this sort of inclusion.
  • If colonies are an optional management and gameplay goal which provide bonuses to players who want to interact with such features then I really have no criticism. Optional gameplay elements are great, I might even be compelled to set up a single colony for some reason. However, ideally I should be able to go interstellar using ONLY infrastructure within Kerbin SOI.
  • If colonies are a required gameplay element but have no real management input beyond creating a structure and optimization, then the game should provide unoptimized prefab colonies that can be plopped down and ignored. The ideal gameplay will involve me simply trucking the building components to where they are needed, hitting the start button, and walking away with my requirements fulfilled. That honestly sounds like uninteresting gameplay so for the sake of both people who want colonies and those of us who don't, I hope this one isn't being considered.
  • If colonies are an optional gameplay element but have no real management input beyond creating a structure and optimization, then I really have to ask what they're doing in the game? Refueling depots? Is that it?

This is of great interest to me as I'm considering buying in to an early access program and may be stuck with gameplay elements that I do not like later in development.

Edited December 14, 2022 by regex

Since colonies will be in the background most of the time, I think its fair to say that colonies will require little to no active management (as in you wont need to stop what youre doing to manage them, once theyre set up theyre good). Most of the gameplay from them is most likely going to be based around construction and design of these colonies. I think this would fit ksp's style of gameplay the best, and fit the fact that youll spend years in timewarp means these things have to run in the background for long periods of time. That being said, there's probably going to be an option to give colonies infinite resources that way you can play sandbox mode but with science progression.

The mechanical purpose of colonies will most likely be primarily resource extraction, part generation, launch sites, and probably science generation. Youll need resources to build spaceships, and colonies will provide this. With interstellar travel, multiple launch sites will be needed for rockets not launched from ksp, this is what resource extraction will feed back into. Colonies will probably feed back into science some way? Considering that colonies will host many kerbals and those kerbals need to do something. 

Resource extraction will definitely try to push you outwards as exploring other worlds is what ksp is all about. Its impossible to say how tight this will be, but I think its fair to say that youll be required to go interplanetary before you go interstellar, as the devs will want players to explore as much as possible.

Tough for me to be unbiased here because colonies are probably the thing that Im most excited for in KSP2. Now, while I personally could have a super in-depth and involved colony system I do of course recognize that colonies are there to serve the deeper gameplay of space travel and not the other way around. Obviously none of us knows exactly what this will look like just yet, but the gist I get from the way Nate talks about it they're trying to keep actual management as streamlined and set-and-forget as they can so players can time-warp on long missions and not worry that things will fall apart on all their bases--so I guess that would fit into "structure and optimization". As far as whether they're required or not I couldn't say for sure but I bet the answer is "sort of". It sounds like within progression mode you will have to go out and explore and collect and resources from other planets before you can advance your tech all the way up to interstellar drives. Now, whether you absolutely need a local colony to do that I couldn't be sure, but some of the advanced fuel manufacturing facilities look much too huge to launch from KSC. I suspect you'll be placing them with the BAE interface. We also don't know a whole lot about the science system or whether you'll need off-world labs to do in-the-field research to feasibly climb all the way to the top of the tech tree. To me that would be fine. This is a much bigger game and I personally think it would be a shame if it was just about flags and footprints. I suspect you wouldn't agree. 

As to the underlying question "(will I) be able to go interstellar using ONLY infrastructure within Kerbin SOI" in progression mode the answer might be yes, but probably with some difficulty. I certainly wouldn't want progression to be balanced in a way that you didn't have to at least visit 3-4 other planets before you could earn interstellar engine tech. You might also have to plow through a lot of resource processing nodes on the tech tree that you didn't end up using because you skipped building colonies. I do however think there could be a bit of a loophole for players who preferred to move most of their equipment from KSC rather than taking advantage of off-world VABs. Allow me to once again plug my "KSC Resource Depot Idea (TM)" *Jamaican air horn*. Since there's no money it would be great if parts still had resource costs at KSC but those resources were generated over time and hit a cap that could be upgraded using science. With enough science you might even be able to upgrade it to the point where you could produce advanced interstellar fuels at KSC and then deliver them to your orbital platform. This would make at least a path for players who prefer to play from home rather than getting deeply invested in building colonies everywhere.

Why can't we manufacture parts in orbit? Truck in materials from asteroids, get fuel using Kuck Mosquitoes or something? Why would I spend my resources on colonies when I'm trying to build an interstellar ship?

I think this probably will be an option if you want to do it that way. Based on how the transport logistics and repeatable supply missions have been described, if you want to skip building a surface base you probably will be able to. You would instead build a reusable mining lander, fly it to the resources on the Mun or Minmus, or capture and mine asteroids, and fly the materials back to an orbital base for refining and construction. And have that repeat. I don't know if anything discussed yet will absolutely require a surface base. Maybe the raw ore will be much heavier and bulkier than refined products, giving you an incentive to haul them to a ground colony first via rovers and refine first for lighter smaller payloads, delivering more finished material to orbit per trip.

 

If I had to guess, I also think kerbin will supply almost all the resources needed, except for only the most exotic materials like maybe antimatter. But, I'm hoping, the supply won't be unlimited. It will be mined at a rate, x number of x resource per day. Then, because of the deeper gravity we'll, you have to use a lot of those limited resources to build a and fuel a rocket to lift some to orbit.

(In the career/explore mode obviously. In science mod they would be unlimited)

So, you could simply wait months to accrue enough resources to build a huge orbital ship from kerbin. Or instead, you could supplement this with colonies on the mun and minmus, doubling or tripling monthly output. Allowing you to build more rockets faster.

 

I don't expect the system to be implemented in a way where there is only one answer. You must do it this way with all of this. It is ksp at its heart. There will be resources on one end. We build a huge ship in orbit at the other. All the steps in between could be done on dozens of ways, some smarter and easier than others. 

 

You could build huge ground colonies to refine and produce your parts to supply the orbital yard. You could skip the ground and mine with landers to feed the orbital yard. You could use only what kerbin gives you. But some ways will be easier and faster.

 

 

As for colony management, we've seen four big things that are clues. 1, colonies will need power and maybe lots of it to make use of those big reactors. 2, colonies will need food, or something from those greenhouses. 3, colonies will have a population of kerbals, to make use of all those habitat and housing parts. 4 colonies can refine materials, if only fuels.

I expect all the industrial buildings including the VAB, to require a certain amount of power and a certain amount of kerbals. If the requirements aren't met, maybe the work buildings don't function or maybe they function at reduced capacity.

I don't expect kerbals to die, except maybe on a hard difficulty, but maybe they go on strike or work at reduced output if not provided with food, recreation, and such.

All of these things would be a fraction sort of thing. 40/50 power, 60/70 kerbals, 10/20 recreation spots, 30/40 snacks. If you're supplying enough all is well forever. If not, reduced efficiency or no production. As these colonies need to be self sufficient enough that they don't bother you while you're off doing something else.

And there were a lot of options. You could build a surface refinery, and haul fuel to orbit. You could have your refinery in orbit and haul up ore. You vould have your refinery equipment on the lander itself. You could have a huge fuel station you keep topped up. Or you could deliver fuel directly to a vehicle. The fuel could come up from kerbin, at the cost of having to exit heavier gravity.

 

Ksp is a game of parts at its core. There will be parts to mine raw resources, parts to refine resources. And parts to use the resources to build colony buildings or vessels. Now, some parts might be so large they have to be in a permanent colony, on the surface or in orbit. But apart from that, I don't expect we will be told you must use the parts in a certain way, this must be here and that must be there. So that naturally will create lots of different ways of doing something.
